description: Primes p such that 3 is a square mod p.
comments: Also primes congruent to {1, 2, 3, 11} mod 12.The subsequence p = 1 (mod 4) corresponds to A068228 and only these entries of a(n) are squares mod 3 (from the quadratic reciprocity law). - _Lekraj Beedassy_, Jul 21 2004Largest prime factors of n^2 - 3. - _Vladimir Joseph Stephan Orlovsky_, Aug 12 2009Aside from 2 and 3, primes p such that Legendre(3, p) = 1. Bolker asserts there are infinitely many of these primes. - _Alonso del Arte_, Nov 25 2015
references: Ethan D. Bolker, Elementary Number Theory: An Algebraic Approach. Mineola, New York: Dover Publications (1969, reprinted 2007): p. 74, Theorem 25.3.
links: Vincenzo Librandi, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1000
example: 11 is in the sequence since the equation x^2 - 11y = 3 has solutions, such as x = 5, y = 2.13 is in the sequence since the equation x^2 - 13y = 3 has solutions, such as x = 4, y = 1.17 is not in the sequence because x^2 - 17y = 3 has no solutions in integers; Legendre(3, 17) = -1.
mathematica: Select[Prime[Range[250]], MemberQ[{1, 2, 3, 11}, Mod[#, 12]] &] (* _Vincenzo Librandi_, Aug 08 2012 *)Select[Flatten[Join[{2, 3}, Table[{12n - 1, 12n + 1}, {n, 50}]]], PrimeQ] (* _Alonso del Arte_, Nov 25 2015 *)
prog: (MAGMA) [p: p in PrimesUpTo(1200) | p mod 12 in [1, 2, 3, 11]]; // _Vincenzo Librandi_, Aug 08 2012(PARI) forprime(p=2, 1e3, if(issquare(Mod(3, p)), print1(p , ", "))) \\ _Altug Alkan_, Dec 04 2015
crossrefs: If the first two terms are omitted we get A097933. A040101 is another sequence.
